title: R Tutorials
text:
Resources for learning R programming and working with political science data.


Comprehensive guide to working with congressional data in R:
congressdata.joshuamccrain.com
Topics covered: - Congressional datasets and sources - Data manipulation with tidyverse - Regression discontinuity designs - Working with legislative data - Statistical models for political analysis




Additional tutorials will be added here

For questions or suggestions, contact josh.mccrain@utah.edu.

title: About
text:
I am an Assistant Professor of Political Science at the University of Utah. My research examines American political institutions, with particular focus on Congress, lobbying, media effects, and the use of computational methods in political science.



Ph.D., Political Science, Emory University
M.A., Political Science, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
B.A., Political Science, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill





American political institutions
Congress and Congressional data
Lobbying and money in politics
Media and politics
Policing and police accountability
Public policy and political economy
Computational social science
Causal inference methodologies





Director, Policing Accountability and Policy Evaluation Research Lab





APSA Award for “Revolving Door Lobbyists and the Value of Congressional Staff Connections” (2018, Journal of Politics)





University of Utah, Department of Political Science
Previously: Post-Doctoral Research Associate, Institute for Public Policy and Social Research, Michigan State University
EITM Institute affiliate


For more information, see my full CV or research publications.



Email: josh.mccrain@utah.edu University Profile: University of Utah Faculty Page

title: Joshua M. McCrain
text:
University of Utah

Welcome to my website! I’m an Assistant Professor of Political Science at the University of Utah. My research focuses on American political institutions, Congress, lobbying, media and politics, and computational social science.



Publications: Over 90 academic publications examining Congressional behavior, lobbying dynamics, and political accountability
Research Focus: Congressional data analysis, revolving door phenomena, local news and politics
Teaching: Courses in American Politics, Congressional Studies, and Political Science methods
